offend.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to make someone angry or upset by doing or saying something that they think is rude, unkind etc
offend.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: His remarks deeply offended many Scottish people.
The careful language is designed not to offend.
Liddy was offended by such a personal question.
offend.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to seem bad or unacceptable to someone
offend.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: A solution must be found that doesn’t offend too many people.
Some of these new buildings really offend the eye  (=look very ugly).
offend.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to commit a crime or crimes
offend.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Many of the young men here are likely to offend again.
offend.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to be against people’s feelings of what is morally acceptable
offend.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Broadcasters have a responsibility not to offend against good taste and decency.
offend.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to do something that is a crime
offend.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: What can be done to stop criminals offending again?
offend.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to make someone angry or upset
offend.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The advertisement was never intended to offend anyone.
